title: 113_s2372
content: The Act is titled the "Federal Cybersecurity Workforce Assessment Act" and includes definitions for key terms. The "Federal Cybersecurity Workforce Assessment Act" defines key terms such as "appropriate congressional committees", "Cybersecurity Work Category", "Data Element Code", "Specialty Area", "Director", and "Secretary". The term "Secretary" in the "Federal Cybersecurity Workforce Assessment Act" refers to the Secretary of Homeland Security. SEC. 3. NATIONAL CYBERSECURITY WORKFORCE MEASUREMENT INITIATIVE. The head of each Federal agency must identify cybersecurity workforce positions, determine primary categories and specialty areas, and assign Data Element Codes aligned with the National Cybersecurity Workforce Framework. Procedures must be established to identify open positions with cybersecurity functions within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The head of each Federal agency must assign employment codes to employees and open positions involved in cybersecurity functions within 9 months of the Act's enactment. A progress report on the implementation of this section must be submitted to congressional committees within 1 year. SEC. 4. IDENTIFICATION OF CYBERSECURITY WORK CATEGORY AND SPECIALTY AREAS OF CRITICAL NEED. Beginning one year after employment codes are assigned to employees, Federal agencies must annually identify critical Cybersecurity Work Categories and Specialty Areas. They must submit a report to the Director describing these areas and providing evidence of their critical need. The Director will offer guidance on identifying areas with skill shortages. The Director, in consultation with the Secretary, will identify Specialty Areas of critical need for cybersecurity workforce across all Federal agencies and submit a progress report on the implementation of this section to the appropriate congressional committees within 18 months of the enactment of this Act. The Comptroller General will analyze and monitor the implementation of sections 3 and 4, submitting a status report to congressional committees within 3 years of the Act's enactment.
